items.title: Parity 1.10 'Opportunity' released.
items.markdown: Parity is continuing its mission to develop trailblazing, next-generation technology for the decentralised web. Today, we announce the first beta release of the Parity Ethereum client version 1.10 'Opportunity'! Read more [on our blog](http://paritytech.io/parity-1-10-opportunity-released/).

items.title: Fighting hunger with a Parity blockchain.
items.markdown: As millions continue to be affected by conflict and natural disasters, the [UN World Food Programme (WFP)](http://wfp.org/) has recognised the potential of blockchain as a tool that can help feed the hungry. Read more [on our blog](http://paritytech.io/fighting-hunger-with-blockchain/).

items.title: Scaling ÐApps with Parity Bridge.
items.markdown: Transaction fees on the Ethereum main network have risen to rates that are far too expensive for ÐApps to run efficiently. Decentralised initiatives such as [Giveth](https://giveth.io/) and [Swarm.City](https://swarm.city/) have seen their projects hampered by high gas costs, forcing them to look for alternative ways to securely run their ÐApps. Read more [on our blog](http://paritytech.io/bridging-the-dapp-scaling-now-with-parity-bridge/).

items.title: Parity enlists Trail of Bits to lead security review.
items.markdown: After receiving many proposals from security auditing firms, we are excited to announce that we have chosen [Trail of Bits](https://www.trailofbits.com/) to review and if indicated, improve the security of our code. Read more [on our blog](http://paritytech.io/parity-technologies-appoints-trail-of-bits-to-lead-security-review/).

items.title: Ropsten Revival
items.markdown:
We are pleased to [announce](https://github.com/ethereum/ropsten/blob/master/revival.md) that the Ropsten testnet has been revived! Thanks to a generous donation of GPU hashpower, the Ropsten chain has been cleared of the spam blocks that had accumulated in a [recent attack](http://ethereum.stackexchange.com/q/12477).

While there is a trend toward adoption of alternative [proof-of-authority](https://github.com/paritytech/parity/wiki/Proof-of-Authority-Chains) consensus protocols for Ethereum testnets, such as [Kovan](https://github.com/kovan-testnet/proposal), Ropsten as a public proof-of-work Ethereum testnet remains relevant for multiple reasons.

Since the Ethereum mainnet still operates based on PoW consensus, a PoW testnet best reproduces the current production environment, i.e., system and network conditions on the live Ethereum mainnet. Thus, Ropsten is useful for experiments to investigate certain issues that we observe today on the mainnet, such as the relation between uncle rates and gas prices. And for Dapp developers, Ropsten is useful for realistic tests of back-end performance (i.e., mainnet transactions and block times) and front-end user experience. If you have any questions, join the [gitter chat](http://gitter.im/ethereum/ropsten).

items.title: Questions?
items.markdown:
Have questions? We would like to get them answered. The [Parity wiki](https://wiki.parity.io) should be the first stop for any general questions in running the software, configuring it or just trying out some of the basic or advanced features of Parity, either as a user, developer or miner.

If you prefer direct interaction with the team, join us on our [gitter](https://gitter.im/paritytech/parity) or [riot](https://riot.im/app/#/room/#parity-watercooler:matrix.org) channel and feel free to ask any questions.
